sections.title: SECTION 1: WHAT IS A CELL? (FOUNDATIONS)
sections.summary: Learn what cells are, what they do to stay alive, and why cell size, DNA, and division matter for understanding cancer.

subsections.title: 1.1 What Is a Cell and Why It Matters
subsections.description: Define what a cell is, what cells must do to stay alive, and how cell teamwork supports the whole organism.
text: 1.1 what is a cell and why it matters focuses on the biological processes involved and how cells normally behave in this situation. It highlights why precise control is important for keeping tissues healthy.
When these processes are disrupted, cells may begin to grow, divide, or survive in abnormal ways. Understanding this concept helps explain how cancer develops step by step rather than all at once.

questions.question: ⁠What is a cell?
options: A group of tissues working together
The smallest unit of life capable of carrying out vital functions
A molecule that stores genetic information
A structure found only in animals
questions.explanation: A cell is the basic unit of life. It can carry out essential functions like using energy, maintaining balance, and reproducing.

questions.question: ⁠Which of the following is a function cells must perform to stay alive?
options: Produce electricity
Repair damage
Absorb sunlight
Move between organs
questions.explanation: Cells must maintain homeostasis. Repairing damage helps keep important structures (like DNA and membranes) working properly.

questions.question: Why must cells in multicellular organisms cooperate?
options: Cells cannot survive on their own
Cooperation benefits the organism as a whole
Cells share DNA with each other
Cooperation prevents all mutations
questions.explanation: Specialized cells work together so the organism can perform complex tasks efficiently and stay alive.

questions.question: ⁠What does it mean when cells “respond to signals”
options: They communicate using nerves
They react to instructions from their environment
They send electrical impulses
They divide continuously
questions.explanation: Cells detect messages from their environment and other cells, then adjust behavior like growth, movement, or division.

questions.question: Why would a cell ignoring signals be dangerous?
options: It would run out of energy
It could damage nearby cells
It might behave in ways that harm the organism
It would immediately die
questions.explanation: Ignoring signals can lead to harmful behavior, and serious stress signals can even trigger cell death pathways.

subsections.title: 1.2 Cellular Organization and Compartmentalization
subsections.description: Learn how cells are organized into parts (organelles) and why having compartments makes cell processes more efficient.

When these processes are disrupted, cells may begin to grow, divide, or survive in abnormal ways. Understanding this concept helps explain how cancer develops step by step rather than all at once.

questions.question: Why do cells divide?
options: To increase their size
To grow, repair damage, and replace old cells
To avoid mutations
To create energy
questions.explanation: Division makes new cells for growth and for replacing cells lost to wear, injury, or normal cell death.

questions.question: What does the surface-area-to-volume ratio describe?
options: How fast cells divide
How much DNA a cell contains
The relationship between cell size and exchange efficiency
The number of organelles in a cell
questions.explanation: As a cell gets bigger, volume grows faster than surface area, making exchange across the membrane less efficient.

questions.question: Why can’t cells just grow larger instead of dividing?
options: Large cells cannot make proteins
Large cells cannot store DNA
Exchange of nutrients and waste becomes inefficient
Large cells divide too quickly
questions.explanation: Very large cells struggle to bring in enough nutrients and remove wastes quickly, so dividing is more efficient.

questions.question: What is DNA replication?
options: The repair of damaged DNA
The copying of DNA before cell division
The movement of DNA within the nucleus
The destruction of old DNA
questions.explanation: DNA replication is copying DNA so each new cell gets a complete set of genetic instructions.

questions.question: What is a mutation?
options: A temporary change in cell behavior
A permanent change in the DNA sequence
A type of cell division
A signal from another cell
questions.explanation: A mutation is a permanent change in the DNA sequence. It can change proteins and affect cell behavior.

questions.question: Why does repeated cell division increase cancer risk?
options: Cells become weaker over time
DNA replication is always inaccurate
Mutations can accumulate over many divisions
Cells lose their membrane
questions.explanation: Every DNA copy can introduce errors. Over many divisions, mutations can accumulate and raise cancer risk.

questions.question: what is cancer?
options: A disease where cells never divide
A group of diseases where some cells grow uncontrollably
A condition where all cells become bacteria
A disease caused only by a lack of vitamins
questions.explanation: Cancer involves abnormal cells growing and dividing without proper control.

questions.question: What usually controls when cells divide?
options: Random chance
Signals and checkpoints in the cell cycle
Only the heart
Gravity
questions.explanation: Cells follow signals and checkpoints that regulate division.

sections.summary: Understand cancer as uncontrolled cell growth, how tumors form, and why cancer develops through many changes over time.

subsections.title: 2.1 What Is Cancer?
subsections.description: Introduce cancer, tumors, and the difference between controlled growth and growth that escapes regulation.
text: 2.1 what is cancer? focuses on the biological processes involved and how cells normally behave in this situation. It highlights why precise control is important for keeping tissues healthy.
When these processes are disrupted, cells may begin to grow, divide, or survive in abnormal ways. Understanding this concept helps explain how cancer develops step by step rather than all at once.

questions.question: What is a tumor?
options: A group of dying cells
A mass of cells formed when division exceeds cell death
A type of infection
A damaged organ
questions.explanation: A tumor is a mass of cells that forms when cell division exceeds cell death and normal tissue controls.

questions.question: What is the key difference between benign and malignant tumors?
options: Size
Speed of growth
Ability to invade and spread
Number of cells
questions.explanation: Malignant tumors can invade nearby tissues and spread to other parts of the body; benign tumors usually stay localized.

questions.question: Which type of tumor is considered cancer?
options: Benign
Temporary
Malignant
Regulated
questions.explanation: Malignant tumors are cancerous because they can invade surrounding tissue and may spread.

questions.question: Why is cancer described as a disease of broken regulation?
options: Cancer cells divide too slowly
Cancer cells lose normal growth controls
Cancer cells lack DNA
Cancer cells cannot repair damage
questions.explanation: Cancer forms when normal growth controls fail, allowing cells to keep dividing when they shouldn’t.

questions.question: Why does cancer usually develop over a long time?
options: Tumors grow very slowly
Cells divide infrequently
Multiple changes must accumulate in cells
Cancer only occurs in old cells
questions.explanation: Cancer often needs multiple changes to build up in a cell, which usually takes time.

questions.question: Why does cancer risk increase with age?
options: Older cells divide faster
The immune system stops working
Cells have more time to accumulate harmful changes
Aging directly causes tumors
questions.explanation: Over time, cells experience more divisions and more chances for DNA damage and harmful mutations to accumulate.

text: 6.2 epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (emt) focuses on the biological processes involved and how cells normally behave in this situation. It highlights why precise control is important for keeping tissues healthy.
When these processes are disrupted, cells may begin to grow, divide, or survive in abnormal ways. Understanding this concept helps explain how cancer develops step by step rather than all at once.

questions.question: what is cancer?
options: A disease where cells never divide
A group of diseases where some cells grow uncontrollably
A condition where all cells become bacteria
A disease caused only by a lack of vitamins
questions.explanation: Cancer involves abnormal cells growing and dividing without proper control.

questions.question: What usually controls when cells divide?
options: Random chance
Signals and checkpoints in the cell cycle
Only the heart
Gravity
questions.explanation: Cells follow signals and checkpoints that regulate division.
